awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Selecting Sensors and Actuators for Topologically Evolving Networked Dynamical Systems: Battling Contamination in Water Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this project is the dynamic management of sensors and actuators in networked systems with applications to minimizing contamination in drinking water networks. A defining feature of modern infrastructures is the prevalence and abundance of real-time sensing and actuation devices. The increased integration of smart communities through Internet-enabled devices will achieve superior system-level infrastructure performance and reliability. Power grids, water systems, and transportation networks share billions of sensors and actuators amongst them. Although the exponential increase in the number of sensing and actuating devices offers an abundance of societal merits, the real-time management of these devices becomes a daunting task for system stakeholders. The dynamic deployment of sensors and actuators, actuators implementing optimal actions, and sensors selectively reporting time- and space-critical data, will lead to significant socio-economic gains. The specific themes addressed by this project are curbing contamination levels in water distribution networks and reducing energy consumption in power grids. 

The research goal of this project is to create fundamental scientific methods that guide networked systems stakeholders in the adaptive selection of the most reliable sensors and actuators--amid the inevitable topologically evolution and uncertainty in these systems. The low- or high-frequency topological evolution is a natural consequence of the physical changes in networked systems. For example, the addition of nodes and links in networks causes a change in topology. Related prior work focused on problems of scheduling or one-time placement of sensors and actuators for mostly linear systems. In contrast, this research investigates methods for adaptively selecting sensing and actuating devices as network conditions change, in addition to considering a wide range of control-theoretic metrics. Such an approach significantly enhances the resilience of networked systems and infrastructures to changes in topology, in addition to ensuring robustness against uncertainty. The investigated research also has important impacts on quality control of contamination-free water distribution networks that leverage high-end mobile water sensors traversing pipes and tanks, while acquiring data through wireless communications every few seconds. Exploiting the slow time-scales of water networks, optimal and sub-optimal online algorithms are developed based on semidefinite and mixed-integer programming. These algorithms capitalize on the inherent sparsity of networked systems to obtain the optimal timing and location of decontaminant injections, acting as actuators, while simultaneously sampling data from mobile water sensors. This can ultimately guarantee a minimal level of contamination in drink water networks.

por.por_cntn:
Infrastructure such as water distribution networks (WDNs), transportation systems, and power grids are networked dynamical systems (NDSs) with large and increasing numbers of sensing and actuator devices. Societal welfare is contingent upon the reliable, economic, and seamless operation of these networks, which can only be ensured by effectively optimizing the operation of their sensors and actuators (SaAs). Where and when SaAs are placed still present monumental questions for experts in this field, questions that are socio-economically imperative. With a large number of advanced SaAs in NDSs, three fundamental questions are posed and addressed in this award: (a) How can SaAs be selected in near real-time? (b) How does the importance of SaAs vary with the evolution of NDS topology? (c) How can infrastructure such as WDNs socio-economically benefit from active selection of SaAs?

To that end, the high-level objective of this award is to create domain-independent scientific methods that guide NDS stakeholders in the real-time, adaptive selection of the most reliable SaAs in topologically evolving NDSs, i.e., NDSs that form changing networks. In a conceivable future world of interconnected NDSs, the smart and timely deployment of SaAs---actuators that determine optimal control actions and sensors that cherry-pick time-critical data---will lead to monumental socio-economic gains. This award applies the theoretical framework to WDNs, and in particular, to battle the effects of contaminants. WDNs should provide uninterrupted supply of safe drinking water to all consumers, and thus, there is a pressing need to ensure that populations are minimally exposed to contamination in WDNs. Due to aging infrastructure, water utilities face the great challenge of increasing security and resilience of WDNs against contaminants, while optimizing network operation and consumption. This project develops theoretical methods to schedule SaAs with specific applications to water quality in drinking water networks.  This award also consider uncertainty in NDSs in general, and WDNs in specific. The uncertainty in NDSs is due to potential cyber-attacks, SaA malfunctions, and unknown disturbances. 

 

The specifical intellectual merit of the proposed methods are: (1) A domain-independent framework that guides real-time selection of SaAs for uncertain and linear NDSs with topological evolution in the network structure. (2) Holistic mathematical models for operation of NDSs with dynamic selection of SaAs under SaA malfunctions and potential data-attacks. (3) Computationally scalable optimization methods of SaA selection with operational constraints to control and diagnose individual systems. (4) Domain-specific knowledge through the application of the developed methods to WDN water quality- and hydraulics-related problems. The methods put forth in this award will significantly upgrade the operation of WDNs---a domain of profound societal importance. The safety and resilience of WDNs is expected to be significantly enhanced. The proposed framework lends itself to fast-reacting automated procedures that can identify, protect, and dynamically eliminate contaminants that can severely affect public health. Even though the focus of the methods will be on deliberate contaminant events, they can also be applied to unintentional contamination incidents, which are far more frequent. The novel techniques developed here have the potential to address other WDNs-related questions such as leakage detection and infrastructure rehabilitation.
